reviewText:
If Cave Story was Metroid, Kero Blaster is Contra.

Completely linear, your objective is always to get to the end of the stage to fight a boss, and then do it all over again on the next. Next to no backtracking or branching paths, but there are a few hidden areas that reward you with money or extra lives. Checkpoints happen on almost every single screen transition, so deaths don't set you back too far nor do you need to remember to hit up a save point. However once you run out of lives, you're sent back to the start of the level, but you get to keep all of your money. So some of the harder bosses get eaiser on multiple tries, since you have more money for better upgrades each time you attempt it.

As for an actual review, it's easy to tell the game was first made for a touch device, with the slightly awkard shooting controls. When you hold fire down, you lock your view to that direction, but can still move freely. After a stage or two it starts feeling normal. The first playthrough is fairly easy, with a few annoying boss fights, but the second playthrough ZANGYOU" (Overtime) is where the real difficulity is at. The second time through all of the stages get tweaks to their layout
date: while still keeping the overall shape of the area the same. All of the weapons feel like they have some use
recommended: which is good since there aren't many even with the upgrades.\n\nWhile there's not as much character development or plot as Cave Story
hoursPlayed: there's still plot and dialog between stages
voteText: and the 2nd playthrough has its own as well. However if you enjoyed Cave Story for its music
helpfulPercent: Kero Blaster does not dissapoint. Overall
votesTotal: its a fun game to play through
votesFunny:
worth the base $10 to me.

Pink Hour and Pink Heaven are both demos for Kero Blaster.
(Played when it wasn't available on Steam)"

reviewText: A pretty excellent shooter with a great soundtrack. Everything in the weapons, levels, and enemies feels meticulously tuned to perfection. I love all the odd little gameplay homages to games from my childhood: Mickey's Mousecapade, Megaman, Adventure Island, Mario World, TMNT, etc.\n\nIt's not as big a story as Cave Story, but the goofy office characters are much easier to relate to. The Hard mode is actually a new story with new levels and bosses, so you haven't really completed it until you've done that.
voteText: 19 of 19 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Fun run and gun style platformer from the developer of the highly praised Cave Story. Outside of a few very questionable bosses, the game remains consistently fun. The stages are expertly designed in both layout and enemy placement in order to give a lot of diversity of feel to a game without a huge amount of mechanical depth as well as encouraging the player to use all of the different weapons the game has to offer. It is very difficult to get through the game exclusively using one weapon.

The base game is pretty short (around 2-3 hours) however there is a fair bit of bonus content. In particular, ZANGYOU mode is a hard mode which ramps the difficulty up quite a bit and adds some new content and dialogue in as well.

Overall this game is a masterfully crafted experience that is simple to play but has enough diversity to never wear itself out. Fun gameplay, a cute aesthetic, and amazing music make this game highly recommended from me, even at the full price. Further, there are two free pseudo-demos called Pink Hour" and "Pink Heaven" which contain similar gameplay though shorter and easier. If you are unsure about purchasing this I would recommend giving them a shot first."

reviewText: As a big fan of Cave Story, I was really excited to hear they were making a new game that looks and feels like it. Kero Blaster is, however, more straightforward and linear than Cave Story. I love how you upgrade your weapons, the story is really funny, the soundtrack is brilliant. Although somewhat short, I know I am going to play this through again and again just because it is so much fun to play.

reviewText:
Compared to Cave Story? It's a step backward in complexity since it's very linear, but it has just as much charm to it, maybe even more. Everything is cute and unexplained, which really make it feel like an old-school game.

ribbit

If you are going to play this game, expect Cave Story but with a frog instead of a robot.

The gameplay is pretty much like Cave Story, but kinda more challenging, also you get coins and buy the upgrades with them instead of getting yellow triangle... things. Sadly, the game is pretty short, even with Zangyou and Omake modes, I promise you'll never want this game to end.

The soundtrack is pretty much like Cave Story's, but the engine it uses is different, however, some songs are just pretty good, the soundtrack may be even better than Cave Story's.

reviewText:
Summary:
Solid but not spectacular is the name of the game with Kero Blaster. You can tell that the guy who created Cave Story is behind it with the art style in question, but it never hits the same level of charm or story that that game did. It's originally an IOS game that feels more at home here, with simple controls but solid gameplay that relies on good level design and basic weaponry to propel it forward. What it doesn't have is anything that hits you in the mouth, aka the knockout punch to really sell the game, as it's solid in most aspects, but not great in any one either. Some elements have problems with boss fights that let down and an overall sense of having played the game before, but for a title to pick up on sale, it will bring back some memories of Cave Story while you play through it, and it is enjoyable. Just don't expect Cave Story 2.

Gameplay Footage and Video Review: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=L0zlBJWN3Xw

Lists:
+:
Strong level design adds to the game's variety over time and helps the simple mechanics succeed thanks to enemy placement and rearranging of hazards.
Simple straight forward gameplay that feels polished, and doesn't go overboard in any one way. Feels like most pieces fit together with no issues.
Difficulty curve is solid as there's a solid progression of it throughout the game, never having large gaps or peaks of difficulty, but a solid rise of it.
Controls feel at home here as opposed to the iOS.
Gun variety is simple but rewards smart use of each gun type and different gameplay styles.
You'll get some nostalgia for those who played Cave Story by the feel of the game.
Jumping takes a bit to get used to for some of the more tricky jumps, but it does settle down once you get an understanding of what the game is going for.
-:
Some boss fights miss badly being basically regular enemies with nothing really new to show for it.
Audio options missing, and screen resolution options are really non existant. Even for a mobile port, it doesn't really do a good job of playing to the Steam strengths.
Some jumps go for the extreme limit of jump height, leading no room for error, and frustration sets in.
Those Expecting Cave Story 2 in terms of charm and story will need to look away, as it never hits that level.

reviewText: I really like this game, but this is not Cave Story. Cave Story was more explorative and had secrets hidden in little nooks and crannies like Super Metroid. Kero Blaster has a very linear progression, akin to something like Mega Man. This linear progression is a big strength, because enemy placement is supurb. I'm not going to go into any story aspects of this game, because I don't want to spoil much, also its not a game with a heavy story. I really enjoyed the stage design, like I said great enemy placement. The pallet choices were good, the pixely aesthetics takes me back to the old days. It's also got a great soundtrack, I mean can you really expect less of the guy who made other games like Cave Story and Ikachan. Studio Pixel did a great job with this release, I know it has been out for some time, but its nice to see it released on steam.\nThe only real downside is that you'll have to grind money off of enemies or die a lot in later stages to get your weapons and life meter maxed out, but grinding doesn't seem like that much of chore because this game can get hard. Especially if you're playing Zangyou Mode which is Kero Blasters new game+/ hard mode. I say pick it up, Its wonderful.

reviewText:
Got this from Playism back when it first came out, they gave me a Steam key to boot!

Kero Blaster is a fun little game. It's also completely linear, so don't go into it expecting another Cave Story! Not too long, but it's fun every minute. Once you beat the normal game, you unlock a special hard mode (with heavily redesigned stages, and some new enemies and bosses, plus a new story), and after that, a New Game+.

The game has a great soundtrack in Pixel's classic style. Where the game really shines in my opinion is how solid the mechanics are. All of the weapons are unique, useful, and fun to use (not to mention upgrade). The boss fights are great, and I always feel like I'm challenged just the right amount by them. The story is hardly very deep, but it's nevertheless charming. The bottom line is that it feels right and is fun to play, as long as you enjoy platformer-shooters.

reviewText:
Kero Blaster is overall a great game. It has much charm and kept me hooked enough to unlock and beat all of the main content it could offer. Some may find the story lacking but I prefer this approach as opposed to too much dialogue or too many cutscenes. My only complaints have to do with a few very questionable design decisions that I feel keep it from being one of my top favorites.

There is an impressive controls menu that shows you a whole keyboard to map as you please. I did not play the game with a gamepad so I can't speak for that. I did not notice any input delay or lag while actually playing at any point which is so important in a game like this. You cannot use the mouse to navigate any of the menus though which seems like a pointless limitation. There is a scaling option but it does not work in fullscreen. Such a thing is easy to program, I have done so myself, and I'm disappointed to not see it there as I have poor eyesight and particularly benefit from this feature.

The weapons are designed very well. They all feel unique and serve their own purpose. You may find a favorite weapon but at least every now and then you'll need to take out another one to get an enemy around a corner or beat enemies in a much more efficient way.

The enemies themselves are very fair once you learn how they work and often require you to learn a new strategy to kill of them without taking damage. Some enemies don't hurt you unless you attack them and you can walk through them or bounce on them freely which came as a nice surprise as they were annoying otherwise.

You can upgrade weapons and boost your maximum health at certain points in the game. These are usually around halfway through a level, and you're left guessing as to where that is exactly. I felt very relieved whenever I saw one for the first time for each level because I knew it likely meant I got to refill my precious health or get a very welcomed upgrade to help me tackle enemies, sometimes in new ways. The prices are very high however, and I assume this is as a result of one of those questionable decisions I briefly mentioned.

You've got a finite amount of lives. When you die, you lose one and start back and the most recent save, otherwise there is no penalty for death. You do not lose any money by simply dying whatsoever. Saves happen very very often. When you lose all of your lives you get a 'Game Over' which starts you at the beginning of the level with everything you had before and 3 lives. If you happen to be low on health, beyond the rare store or beating the level your only opportunity to gain health is to kill an enemy and hope he drops some. It doesn't happen very often. Sometimes you'll carefully clear out an entire room and only get money. Sometimes you'll kill an enemy to restore three health even if you didn't need it. Sometimes they'll drop an extra life which is a big deal because a life is a free pass to restore all your health essentially.

Every time a level transitions all normal enemies respawn, enabling players to farm health and upgrades. If you're having trouble with a level or boss but only have one life left, then your best option is either to farm rooms and cross your fingers really hard or kill yourself and get three lives. Why not, you'll be back where you started but with a huge advantage in comparison. No real punishment other than consuming your time. I don't think beating a level restores your lives either. While on paper this system may look good, I believe it encouraged the developer to allow elements of trial and error to be introduced and balance things in such a way that accounts for players being more powerful than they would otherwise. It's okay if something is cheap because there's, again, no real punishment. I would much rather have lost all of my progress including the upgrades I bought that level if it meant that the game was more exciting and fair.

The platforming physics are frustrating. They're not buggy and work the way they are supposed to, it's just that they're so intentionally clunky. Movement on the ground is fine but your air control is so painfully lacking that I lost count of how many times I saw my fate at least a second away but could do nothing meaningful even with the jetpack. This happened to me a couple times with things that I had no way of knowing were coming too. Some would call that artificial difficulty"
date: I just think it's bad design in a game of this sort.\n\nIf you hold the shoot button in a certain direction
recommended: you're stuck aiming in that direction as you are moving. It's very helpful but you can't toggle in the menu or hold a key to activate/disactivate on hold whenever is appropriate. The way you aim horizontally is also determined by your momentum if not standing still
hoursPlayed: which makes this mechanic feel very sticky. If you stop shooting in a direction to shoot something that just came up behind you
voteText: you can't quickly flip in that direction and you have to unintuitively wait until the character can turn around.\n\nYou have four/five weapons to choose from eventually and have to switch between them one at a time which does not feel good. This is a computer game with rebindable keys
helpfulPercent: not a console game. I assume it supports a controller but there's no good reason why I can't have a key on my keyboard to select each of those weapons in particular once I get them at least.\n\nI would like to add context to these complaints by adding that I have beaten the true final boss of the freeware version Cave Story (can't write this review without mentioning it at least once) with just under the max health and without any health potions (unintentional gimp). I never felt like Kero Blaster was too hard
votesHelpful:
it's simply that it can be frustrating for the wrong reasons.

There is a boss rush mode but by the point you get there the game becomes too easy for it to be satisfying in my opinion. There's a timer though and you can easily play it again to improve that time. You can also of course intentionally put handicaps on yourself by not buying upgrades or starting a new file if you lose all your lives.

Again

reviewText:
UPDATED:

I got nothing interesting to say about the game but here goes nothing. This is one of those well made games that don't revolutionize anything but just works. It's an action platformer, with lots of variety of environments and enemies. It has a finite number of lives system, that sends you back to the beginning of the level when you run out of it and to the beginning of the screen when you lose one life.

The game self regulates the difficulty with its upgrade system. Each time you die you keep all your money, so eventually you'll beat whatever part you're stuck by simply having more fire power. Bosses don't have to be beaten ever again! which is nice considering they are not only difficult but quite long. In my previous review I didn't notice that and almost gave up on the game because I didn't want to fight a specific boss again.

I liked it. If you want some platforming action fun, this game is for everyone basically. I can't think of any demographic that wouldn't get a kick out of it.

reviewText: This Is A Very good game.

Kero Blaster is a bit of an odd duck. It's the second major release from lone auteur game designer Pixel, who about a decade ago created the absolutely legendary Cave Story. Pixel has made a few small games here and there since then, but this is his second major retail release.

Let me say first that if you liked Cave Story, you'll like Kero Blaster, and that's really because it's just more of the same. A few of the mechanics are changed up here and there and there's a much heavier emphasis on arcadey action than plot and characters, but when you get down to the shooty pew pew bits it plays exactly like Cave Story did.
Something that fans of Cave Story may not like, however, is that Kero Blaster is short, and comparitively easy. Veterans of Pixel's works will have no trouble breasing through the campaign. If, however, you are new to Pixel's games, then Kero Blaster would be an excellent start.

From a personal view, I enjoyed the game a lot, but I did find it lacking in some regards. The prologue" game Pink Hour gave the impression that Kero Blaster would
recommended: be a story driven exploration game rather than a linear arcade shooter
hoursPlayed: and I get the distinct impression that was the original intention. Environments are detailed and interesting
voteText: and buyable upgrades are priced in such a way as to suggest a longer game. I feel like Kero Blaster is a game that the devoloper got bored of and just wanted to get out the door so he could move on to something new. This is supported by most of the music
votesHelpful: and even some of the assets and sprites being recycled from Cave Story
votesTotal: which is odd when Pixel is well known for his MIDI music and pixel art
votesFunny:
AND because there were new sprites and music in PInk Hour.

Here's the break down:

Pros
- Fun
commentsCount: high action shooter with extremely tight controls.\n- Four interesting weapons to choose from
column16:
each one feeling unique and special.
- What new sprites there are are cute and endearing.

Cons
- Short
column17: perhaps three hours if you have a lot of trouble
column18: and two if you don't.\n- There's very little story. What's there is cute and funny
column19: but it feels rushed.\n- The entire game has an aire of partialness
column20: like this is only part of a game. A really good part to be sure
column22: I recommend Kero Blaster because it's a fun little diversion
column23: but since it's so short and lacking in plot
column24: it'd be best if you picked it up on sale. The base price is a little much for what you get
column25: but it's still a great game.\n"

reviewText:
First Impression Video:
https://youtu.be/X1KZw9NNxKs

Kero Blaster is a simple, linear platformer by the same people who made Cave Story. To start off, if you're looking for a veritable Cave Story 2, this isn't it. Kero blaster is less Metroidvania and more Arcade side scroller.

In the game you play as a Frog who is part of the Custodial Sciences division of a company and has to kill strange alien creatures. To do so, you have a variety of upgradable weapons to fight with. Health is dealt with in what I would call a mix of Zelda and Mario style. You have a certain number of hearts and when you run out you lose one of the three lives you started with.

I really enjoyed the game so far. The bosses are interesting, the enemies are unexpectedly challenging, and the upgrades are deffinitely worth the gold you spend on them. In addition you have a seemingly simple plot running in the background about the Frog's boss.

Overall if you're looking for a solid Arcade platformer, Kero Blaster is the way to go. It's simple, the controls are tight, and you play as a frog. What more could you ask for?

reviewText: I bought Kero Blaster on playism the day it was originally released, and I was not impressed.  I've been a fan of pixels work for a long time, so it blew my mind that this game was so mediocre.  The game lacked the freedom of movement and challenge of Cave Story. It didn't even have the relaxing atmosphere of ikkachan.  It sat in a boring middle ground; not too easy, but never satisfyingly challenging.  The recent update changed that.\nThe base gameplay is the same as release.  You are a frog that shoots its way through linear levels with various weapons that you obtain as the game progresses.  Gunplay is similar to Cave Story's; with the adition of the ability to shoot while walking backwards and the removal of aiming downward.  You can collect coins when you kill enemies, and these can be spent in shops to upgrade your health and weapons.\nKero Blaster now has an additional campaign that unlocks upon  finishing the original set of levels, and that is where the real fun begins.  While the original levels were boringly easy, the new levels are seriously challenging.  This new set of levels really makes the gameplay shine, and the game now feels like it belongs with pixels other classics.

For the sake of the reader and myself, I've opted to write two reviews: a longform review which is here: http://pastebin.com/d93urqCj , and a summary version which I will write here.

Gameplay: Fairly standard run and gun mechanics; upgradeable weapons are neat but not too terribly deep; some odd level design choices here and there; levels, enemies and bosses for the most part a lot of fun. 8/10.

Story: A lot of character given in fairly few words, some more characterization and explanation of goings on would have been nice. Pretty satisfying overall though. 7/10.

Graphics: Despite slight disparity in some enemy and character design, most of the world and its monsters look very nice. Some kinda disappointing resolution options leading to grey borders on all sides for higher resolutions. Game run s at a perfect 60 FPS. 4/5.

Sound: Definitely a Pixel OST, some very catchy tunes in here. 4/5.

8/7/4/4; 7.7/10. Not revolutionary, but it doesn't need to be.

And when a game evokes one of the finest Ghibli movies made thus far, we have something truly special.\n\nI'm even on the verge of saying I like this better than Cave Story. Sure, it might be a bit hyperbolic of a statement, but it's a true sentiment. Never have I felt a feeling so positive and encouraging. If you like video-games, I feel you should play this. Done deal. (Also play Cave Story if you haven't yet, it's worth it.)

It's an incredibly well done 3 hour game, that gets expanded into a much longer game with the extra content introduced.

reviewText: I like it, although it made me rage quit a few times.

Game was already amazing when it came out a year ago in 2014. But with all the new content in the Steam version, this is simply one of the greatest retro games ever made.

Concise and to the point, KeroBlaster will not waste your time. Every design decision was made with amazing forethought, allowing the simplicity of the game type to aid in the pure complexity of its psychology.

The camera work is always spot-on, enabling the player to make sweeping intelligent decision with relative ease.

The weapons are few because they each serve as a multi-tool swiss army knife, full of surprising functions to use on your endeavors.


To be continued soon....

It's a bit lacking in content compared to the Cave Story, but it's still a great platformer/shmup. You can beat the story mode on normal in 2-3 hours if you're decent at this sort of games.

A cute platformer with fun gameplay and challenging level design, brought to you by the same team who made Cave Story.

In it you play as a frog trying to clear off teleporters that have been infected by a strange shadowy creature. You have multiple different guns to play around with, each with 4-3 tiers of upgrades which can be purchased through coins you collect throughout the levels.

At first the game might seem a bit easy and simplistic, but as you progress the challenge ramps up and the game becomes a blast to play. This challenge increase definitely comes into play with the two extra game-modes which change up the base game in interesting ways and really test the skills you've built up thus far.

All-in-all the game isn't incredibly long but you can easily get 10+ hours out of all of the game-modes. However the game is so much fun and is so well-designed that I think the length shouldn't be too concerning.

Definitely recommended for any 2D platformer fans, or people who enjoyed Cave Story.
Tight platforming action with cute characters and beautiful art, from the same guy that bought you Cave Story.

Run, Gun, and very floatily Jump in this updated version of Kero Blaster.

While at first glance the smaller screen gives the impression that Kero Blaster is a more linearly focused affair than Cave Story, the game in actually quite the opposite. The game leaves weapon and health upgrades in the hands of the player, and depending on skill there's quite a bit of nuance to be had with a playthrough. The generous money system is there to bail players out should things get too frustrating.

Once you finish your first playthrough the new Zangyou Mode becomes available, and this is where Kero Blaster really hits its stride. Remixed stages and and a slew of new enemies and bosses provide a juicy enough side story for new players, as well as a challenging incentive for players who played Kero Blaster the first time around to give the game a second look.

Overall the locations are imaginative, the spritework is charming, and the difficulty is brutal. Walk yourself to the train, you've got a job to do.

I was very worried about this game due to the fact that I thought it would be very different from Cave Story, one of my favorite games also created by Pixel.  I thought the lack of exploration would really detract from the experience.\n\nI was dead wrong!  This game is an absolute blast, and it is filled to the brim with the same quirky charm as Cave Story.  I haven't had this much pure fun with a game in a long time.  Get this game, people!  It's wonderful!

I love Kero Blaster. I love the cute sprite graphics, I love the catchy soundtrack. I love the absurd excuse for a plot. It's a game full of things to love, and without much to dislike.

Like Cave Story, it feels like you're playing a fairy tale; something pure and charming, something unique. Unlike Cave Story, Kero Blaster isn't particularly long or deep, but it is tricky and there are secrets sprinkled here and there.

If you like platformers, or if you just want to play something that will make you happy, buy this game.
I've completed the game 100% and it's a good game!\n10048/10 would hop again and again.

I originally purchased this via Playism, so I assume I've put in around 10-14 hours.  This is a gem of a game.  It should be noted that I'm a complete Pixel fanboy and I love all of his work to death.  Still you should play this game, its a fantastic highly polished little shooter.  The thing that really makes pixel games worth your time is the charm and polish.  This game oozes charm, and the kind that doesn't feel forced.   Its also a top notched expertly designed little action game to boot, the new overdrive mode extends its content even further.   Looking forward to Pixel's next game.

reviewText: This is a great little game that scratched an itch I had. I didn't want to break into another 50 hour open world game, and I loved Cave Story, so this was perfect for me. The graphics are great and well-designed, and the music is up to the amazing standard set by Cave Story. The gameplay is perfect run-and-gun, where you can just let your reflexes take over.\n\nUpdate: I previously said this was pricey, but having played Overtime mode (which essentially is a whole extra game, with a bit of recycled assets), I give this a full-fledged recommendation. The Overtime mode has a nice difficulty ramp-up, like Cave Story did (though not quite as hard). Excellent game.

reviewText: This whimsical run-and-gun displays superhuman levels of polish, as one would expect of the legendary Daisuke Amaya.  It is more leisurely paced than other games of the same genre, like the Contras; success here depends largely on correct weapon selection and intelligent steering of the slow-walking, high-jumping main character.  There may be a lot of games like this, even many that are flashier and faster, but few have the shining spirit, perfect balance, or sense of fun that Kero has.  Truly, it's in a class of its own.  A lot of people are disappointed that the story of the game doesn't follow the same epic science-fantasy track that Cave Story does, and that's a real pity; Kero Blaster's tale of a plasma rifle-toting frog janitor's battle against digital demons and work-producing" machines may not bring a tear to your eye
date: but it's really cute and filled with great ideas.  It's a perfect match for the game type and visual style.\n\nI beat the original Playism version a year ago and loved it
recommended: but didn't think it was quite the equal of the astounding Cave Story.  After having played the considerably spiced-up Steam version
hoursPlayed: I completely take it back!  This new and improved iteration includes "Zangyou" mode:  a hardmode that not only cranks up the difficulty
votesHelpful: a new story and new cutscenes
votesTotal: and completely replaces the last stage with a new huge
votesFunny: awesome level culminating in a gauntlet of bizarre bosses who put anything in normal mode to shame for weirdness.  It's no exaggeration to say that Zangyou
commentsCount: which only unlocks after beating the game once
column16: makes up a good 50% of Kero Blaster's unique content!  Now THAT'S how you do a hardmode!\n\nAnother top-flight game for Pixel's portfolio!"

reviewText: Kero Blaster is a pretty solid platform shooter. Kind of a low-res Cave Story with a similar variety of different guns. And with discrete stages as opposed to an open world. Honestly while good and completely solid in it's own right, I think I expected more, or maybe just something different, from the guy who made Cave Story. I got about 3 hours of gameplay to get through normal mode, and have unlocked a new mode, but haven't tried it yet. It's a solid game, but I'm not sure it's quite worth $10... definitely worth a shot on sale.

The jumping mechanic can be a bit awkward; however, it rarely impacted much as there isn't a whole lot of precision platforming.\n\nDefinitely worth a purchase if you haven't tried it already!

reviewText: Simplistic and fun.\nThat's what old games were all about.\nThat's what this game is.

From the developer of Cave Story, Kero Blaster is a solid game with plenty of polish and sensible design choices. I occasionally found myself going through levels multiple times because I ran out of lives against bosses, but nothing felt particularly unfair, and each new trip through a level rewarded me with enough money to upgrade a weapon or my maximum health.

The levels provide a variety of challenges, from fast paced reaction-based combat with a large group of fast enemies to slow, precision-based platforming. The game organically paces itself by switching up the style of challenge and the speed of gameplay.

It has a wonderful hard mode which is really more of an epilogue (or part 2, I guess), with totally new levels sharing similar themes and bosses, and an entirely different final level with five new boss fights.

A quality game lasting about 8 hours that I'd recommend to anyone who wants a fun, light-hearted jump-and-shoot style platformer.
